Posts.Content: My husbands PSA was over 150 in January, with a combo of hormone treatments and chemo since March ( 6 sessions of 1 hour), with only one more session to go, numbers looking good: 06/26/2015 08:14 0.97 ng/mL (c) 06/11/2015 08:47 1.16 ng/mL (c) 04/24/2015 07:31 3.18 ng/mL (c) 04/03/2015 06:40 5.06 ng/mL (c) My question is, from other experiences, knowing everyone is different, how long will these numbers stay low after chemo stops and its just the hormone treatments, what are the odds?
Posts.Title: Proof that combo Chemo and Hormone Therapy works to lower PSA

Posts.Content: My husbands PSA was over 150 in January, with a combo of hormone treatments and chemo since March ( 6 sessions of 1 hour), with only one more session to go, numbers looking good: 06/26/2015 08:14 0.97 ng/mL (c) 06/11/2015 08:47 1.16 ng/mL (c) 04/24/2015 07:31 3.18 ng/mL (c) 04/03/2015 06:40 5.06 ng/mL (c) My question is, from other experiences, knowing everyone is different, how long will these numbers stay low after chemo stops and its just the hormone treatments, what are the odds?
Posts.Title: Proof that combo Chemo and Hormone Therapy works to lower PSA

Posts.Content: Wow, today took a big turn! Dr says the cancer is doing a major move on his bones! Platelets dropped drastically, they are at 32 now from 213 a month ago. Blood counts are out of wack. LDH is spiked at 561. So a blood transfusion is in the making and if the platelets don't improve, he said there's not much else they can do. They took him off the trial cuz he's not where he needs to be in order for it to work. Overwhelming at this point. I had a feeling it may had attached his bones, but then I thought maybe the drugs were putting a number on his platelets, but not this bad. Not looking good
Posts.Title: Platelet attack!

Posts.Content: We have an appt with Transfusion to receive blood/platelets, hopefully this boost will get him up there and stay where he needs to be, if not, then we will all make him as comfortable as possible. If the platelets don't produce more than likely the cancer has taken over his bones/bone marrow. Thanks for your prayers and comments appreciate it! Keep you all posted.
Posts.Title: Platelet attack!

Posts.Content: Is it wrong to ask how long he's got left, I hate the unknown. I know everyone is different, but I really want to know some sort of time frame. He doesn't want to know but I do. Should I ask the oncologist? I know there's a lot of things to consider but, Im in the mode of wanting to know....
Posts.Title: The Unknown

Posts.Content: So he had his last chemo today...went well...rang the bell )) He loved that! Talked to the oncologist as well, he told the dr about pain he was having in his thigh and calf area. Seems to think its bone pain. Something he hasn't had before the chemo started. So dr ordered a bone scan 5-6 weeks from now. Wants him to recover from the last chemo....I think I will see what the bone scan shows and if its something progressing Im going to have to ask the question. Husband didn't want me too today at all, was very firm about it. So I will wait to see what the bone scan says and take it from there. See how his PSA reacts once chemo is over....thanks all for the response, I will know eventually. He was hoping the chemo killed it all, but its not happening. Dr told him it will suppress it but its not a cure. So hopefully this time he's got it. Diet, exercise and continued treatments will help, gotta keep him chipper, good attitude helps. Once we are done with the follow up and things are good, we plan a trip to GA.

Posts.Title: The Unknown

Posts.Content: 58 yrs old
Posts.Title: High Gleason scores

Posts.Content: Well, #3 injection today.... reality is palliative.... I know he hopes for a cure, but doctors say otherwise, its terminal. Every time he goes in and talks about "when" Im cured or "when" this is over and I can do this" he gets disappointed and depressed every time when they say its killing you, its terminal. So its hard for him to "get it" sometimes. Is it fair to say he puts himself in dreamland to ease the pain of reality? We haven't experienced this before so, cant imagine his brain is in such emotional turmoil I guess you can call it. I see what it does to him. I suggested attending a group but he refuses, he said "God is what I need".... no problem with that So he had his PSA and Testosterone levels done... we are up to 12.04 on his PSA from 10.1 from 1 wk 1/2 ago. Oncologist suggested putting him on Zytiga/Prednisone in conjunction with Lupron to keep his number down, and the radiologist oncologist suggests it will not help his numbers....ok soooo, what such different opinions??
Posts.Title: Radium 233 #3

Posts.Content: I miss that he has no energy to go anywhere and do anything, a trip to the beach over the weekend, he seems not wanting to do and handle, so its sad that we cant do anything in that sense....
Posts.Title: Radium 233 #3

Posts.Content: Do we know the average statistic for survival with patients with a gleason score 9 or higher?
Posts.Title: High Gleason scores

Posts.Content: 58 yrs old
Posts.Title: High Gleason scores

Posts.Content: He's max'd out on all scores, total prostate 10, metastatic prostate, bones, lymph nodes, I guess its hard to say survival rate at this point even with HT. He went from a 157 PSA to a 20 PSA in about a month or so after his first treatment. I did the nomogram and did not give me anything. Other factors came up but not for the prostate cancer because it spread.

Posts.Title: High Gleason scores

Posts.Content: Would there be any reason why a PSA blood work results be different from one lab than the other? curious...
Posts.Title: PSA blood work

Posts.Content: So my husband finished his chemo......with the combo of chemo and hormonal therapy, his PSA is now down to 0.54, previously there were bone mets, done a bone scan last week, no metastatic bone cancer anywhere seen. For some reason I feel that this stuff can play peek a boo?? Does not mean all others are gone, i.e. lymphatic system etc. Can chemo be that accurate on destroying bones mets and boom, nothing on bone scan? A very aggressive cancer, this all can come back, right? This is all just a way of suppressing its progression? Anyone want to chime in on this one? Am I thinking crazy here?
Posts.Title: Progressive Cancer after Chemo....

Posts.Content: So, I understand that with bone mets, there's two things that you can follow in your lab to indicate whether you have an increase in bone mets, cancer that has reached the bones throughout your body. Initially his calcium and alkaline phosphates were increased, not over the limits, but were increased. So Im thinking now that chemo is over, this is something to watch and the PSA levels as far as monitoring cancer spreading to the bones. He does have bone mets in the pelvis, I think one in the spine and now believes has reached his thigh, but the bone scan will tell the tale at the end of August. He complains about pain in one leg, could be muscle/ligament as one had mentioned. Would the chemo he just had be effective enough to kill off the cancer in the bones? Or does this require a different med and avenue to suppress?
Posts.Title: Calcium and Alkaline Phosphate levels

Posts.Content: Anyone here taking hormonal therapy/drugs and have problems with dizziness? Any ideas on how to counteract this problem. My husband has 24/7 issues with it and pretty much causes a lot of his depression because he cant do anything without feeling this way....its frustrating.
Posts.Title: Dizziness

Posts.Content: What about us caregivers (spouse)? Im wondering if they help with that, Im not working, taking care of my hubby, appts, and all the things he's unable to do. Now getting ready to go through Xofigo treatments. Any suggestions, needing supplemental income until his VA is solved.

Posts.Title: SSDI & SSI available for Stage 4 people...

Posts.Content: Does your body have withdrawals when you stop this stuff? Doctor stopped Casodex because it wasn't working and also was trying to find out if it was causing the bad dizziness. Ruling out other causes. But what happens when you are not on a another for the month? Cancer would grow faster without it? He's only stopping it for about a month, then he will put him on something else. But isn't Casodex and Lupron for the same thing, why would he have both? Its like double dosing isn't it?
Posts.Title: Bicalutimide/Casodex

Posts.Content: Ok, that's where my brain was going, and that's what the doctor meant by PSA going down when he stops it....ok well, better understanding then. thanks!
Posts.Title: Bicalutimide/Casodex

Posts.Content: yes, the Dr said malignant, the cancer is causing it, paracentesis maintenance, said it will come back, unless the trial he's on keeps it at bay, but other than that, drainage from time to time to keep pressure and pain away. But it seems majority of patients with this at a late stage gives a meak prognosis.
Posts.Title: Malignant Ascites

Posts.Content: Anyone here experienced ascites yet? Husband just started the draining...5 Liters for his first one, Dr said theres probably still another 3 Liters. How long do you have to wait to drain again. I know theres vascular concerns when doing this? Anyone here have knowledge on this management? I also was reading that this is usually happening towards the end of the journey? Any insight on this too? FYI He's starting to sleep a lil more so its concerning....
Posts.Title: Malignant Ascites

Posts.Content: So husband went back in and had another 2.5Liters drained.....Seems like they got most of it now...time will tell if it comes back or not.....
Posts.Title: Malignant Ascites

Posts.Content: His RBC count is low, below the required range, but WBC is at the lower end of the scale....Platelets seem ok within range...As far as reactions to meds, he just started on Dilaudid, its a very low dose, but thought it would be from his fentanyl patches but he slowed down on those and it still pops up on his skin all over, no specific area, just wherever..

Posts.Title: PSA down, Clean scan!

Posts.Content: Do you mean the mets increased after the treatments?
Posts.Title: PSA down, Clean scan!

Posts.Content: So, husbands bone scan came clean, no changes, and his PSA down to 3.5 after his radium 223 treatments for his bones/pain. Continues on Lupron and Xtandi. No wondering how long this will keep up before we are back to square one!
Posts.Title: PSA down, Clean scan!

Posts.Content: He received 6 treatments. At the beginning of his treatments his PSA was hovering around 14, now its down to about 3.5. Side effects were pretty much fatigue, nausea, it really dragged him out just like radiation does. Now with pain killers etc that he's still on, give him enough down time as it is. So now he's just on Lupron and Xtandi until he becomes resistant again, hopefully not for a long time, but I know its coming. Been on all the other treatments, so whats next who knows, maybe a trial or maybe something else that's been approved to keep him goin. They say Radium 223 buys him about 3 months of relief, but we'll see how it goes.
Posts.Title: PSA down, Clean scan!

Posts.Content: Ok, guys, wondering how this works....Went to Urologist this week, husband told him about a trial he was interested in and Dr said no, you need to try Xofigo now. So Im thinking he wants him to try another drug before you try trials. Makes sense the drugs that are already approved before you try trials, right? Well, bone lesions have increased and his PSA increased the last 3-4 months. Oncologist stopped his biclutamide about a month ago, meanwhile waiting for this trial to kick in, wasting precious time of course, Urologist says no go, time for Xofigo, don't wait for trial. So Im needing any success stories out there with this Radium 233? Isnt this just totally for pain? Or does this actually kill cancer cells? Ive heard both...Im a lil confused on this one. Im thinking if this is just for bone pain, then I come to the conclusion that we are just waiting for dooms day. The oncologist says he can still do the trial while doing Xofigo, just sounds like too much chemical in his poor body. Im thinking the chemicals are going to kill him more than the cancer itself. Thoughts????
Posts.Title: Increased Bone lesions.....Radium 233 (Xotigo) next.....

Posts.Content: well, he has a very aggressive cancer which spread to lymph nodes and bones in the abdominal/pelvic region, so im wondering if extra bone scans are needed to monitor the spread? or is just blood tests monthly are enough to monitor? just because the psa can be lowered really doesn't mean the cancer stopped spreading am I wrong? the treatments can suppress but it continues to spread?
Posts.Title: Bone Scans/Blood Tests

Posts.Content: How often do you need updated bone scans if cancer spread to the bones? And what specific blood tests and numbers should we focus on when its metastatic and on hormonal treatments. Especially if we see it not working, how do we know through monthly blood work?

Let me know your experience, and I know everyone will react differently but at least know what to expect.....

Posts.Content: So, the trial my husband was looking forward too has been dropped due to bad response...now what? Well, he's still on Radium 223 until November, but his PSA is 10 and climbing, still on Lupron, so does this mean Lupron is not working anymore, or is it the Radium that's causing the numbers to go up? Time to try something else I guess...
Posts.Title: Dropped Trial

Posts.Content: yes, correct, Wilde, we discussed it yesterday at his appt. So the Radium continues for now and they are going to put him on Zytiga/Prednisone next in conjunction with the Radium, so see what happens ))
Posts.Title: Dropped Trial

Posts.Content: I know its not so much what level the PSA is as to how much it jumps in a short period of time, correct? So if its 2.4 one month and next month jumps to 3.1, do they consider this alarming? So every month since maybe 5 months ago it has increased, but this one was the biggest jump. How do we consider what difference in numbers needs attention?
Posts.Title: PSA jump

Posts.Content: Yes Michael, oncologist is discontinuing the Casodex for now, not only because the numbers are creeping, but he has a bad case of dizziness he's concerned about, so he's off of it until mid April, then they'll go from there. I think he's going to change the meds anyway.
Posts.Title: PSA jump

Posts.Content: So, confused today on why the doctor ordered a conventional (radioactive tracer) bone scan, knowing that the F18 Sodium Flouride is more accurate!! So the conventional came out negative as I stated above in my other threads, now today doctor said well the conventionals are 50-60% inaccurate, so lets do a F18 Sodium it should do better on showing anything. Ugggg! So his happy happy, went to sappy sappy
Posts.Title: Conventional Bone Scan vs. Sodium Flouride Bone Scan

Posts.Content: Scratch, his PSA is creeping back up (still below 4) and although the conventional scan was negative (which was compared to a year ago), I guess they are concerned about the gradual increase and also he has pain throughout his pelvic region including his back. His numbers are maxed as far as the gleason he was all 10's and its metasticized in pelvic, seminal, lymphatic....and its possible that the pelvic bones are showing signs but it didn't show up. So they recommended the sodium fluoride scan to make sure there is not signs in the bones. If it does they wanted to try the Radium treatments, once a month for 6 mos. I would say that if this scan is all negative, the other recommended imaging will be challenged. Im sure the economical credentialing exists...Im concerned about all the chemicals they feed their patients could end up killing them more than the disease itself.
Posts.Title: Conventional Bone Scan vs. Sodium Flouride Bone Scan

Posts.Content: we have excellent insurance, va, etc. no out of pocket at all, I suppose they find ways to keep us coming back on a regular basis...my husband needs the supervision of care, but if he knew the accuracy to begin with, shame on him I guess. But we will go ahead with it and see, if it comes out negative, the next imaging request will definitely be challenged a lot more than in the past.

Posts.Content: Yes there's quite a bit of white hot spots, I know he has arthritis too so, hopefully the report will be a thorough response....

Posts.Content: Yes there's quite a bit of white hot spots, I know he has arthritis too so, hopefully the report will be a thorough response....
Posts.Title: Injected/Full Body Bone Scan

Posts.Content: So, State 4 aggressive, metastacized, prostate cancer.......right now doing radiation 223 for his bones, dropped the chemo pills didn't work anymore, cant do the trial until the radiation is done.....so, he's in pain, he said he's vomiting at times, food is bothering him, he's just starting to lose some wait. Just started journaling it so not sure of the urgency on that....so I suppose these are symptoms from the radiation treatments he has once a month??
Posts.Title: Stage 4 fun!

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone, I will keep up on posts. Nurse comes in Wednesday to figure out how his pain management regime is coming along. He's been on Morphine, Dilaudid, and Xanax twice a day, seems to work well. Zofran to keep his stomach calm with heartburn med. Still eliminating mucous/blood and some stool not much. His nutrition is made up of broth, some fruit, juices, water, occasional egg, soft foods if he can keep it down. Enjoys his new adjustable bed. Our dog of 5 1/2 yrs sometimes has this weird look like "whats going on". But he's very therapeutic! He does still get around, slow, but he does. The biggest challenge right now is lifting his legs up onto the bed. I do have a question? Is hospice suppose to be doing labs if they are managing his pain or no? They are starting him on a diuretic this week to help with swelling and ascites fluid buildup.
Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: Husband now on hospice care. Went into Moffitt last Monday for a paracentesis, but his blood work was all over the place so had to get his platelets under control in order to do the procedure. Got his platelets up to 76 and got the procedure done. This situation admitted him for a couple days. Blood work was monitored, he got more blood, and changed his pain meds. No more treatments. Dr referred him to hospice. So now he's hooked up with Lifepath Hospice House. He's equipped at home for now where he's more comfortable, he hates hospitals, who doesn't....until any major changes we cant handle here, he's at home. But he has a great team started so lets see where this leads us, one day at a time.
Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: So what are the odds of the high PSA coming back after the combo hormone injection and chemo? What are the odds of PSA numbers increasing again after the chemo is done and only injections follow...for a stage 4....??
Posts.Title: High PSA coming back...

Posts.Content: I think this progressively came about over time but he was diagnosed in 2012 with an enlarged prostate and I believe there were symptoms before and just didn't realize what was going on until the prostate got large enough to cause problems, and then a year later cancer became very aggressive and promoted to metastasized prostate, i.e lymph nodes, bones, pelvic region....started out with hormone therapy injections for about 9 months then combined with chemo as of today, 4 out of 6 sessions so far. So its been three years since initial diagnosis.....we will see how long it will take with these injections before it decides it doesn't like it anymore. Chemo has been tough on him, but overall he's a trooper! It will be interesting to see what happens after the chemo stops and its back to just injections again. Last January his PSA was at around 175, and after we started the chemo with the injections, today its down to 3.19, and his blood work looks good.
Posts.Title: High PSA coming back...

Posts.Content: yes, that's what I thought too, they use it for carcinomas or skin cancers right now I believe...
Posts.Title: Trial/Investigative for Avelumab

Posts.Content: Husband now on hospice care. Went into Moffitt last Monday for a paracentesis, but his blood work was all over the place so had to get his platelets under control in order to do the procedure. Got his platelets up to 76 and got the procedure done. This situation admitted him for a couple days. Blood work was monitored, he got more blood, and changed his pain meds. No more treatments. Dr referred him to hospice. So now he's hooked up with Lifepath Hospice House. He's equipped at home for now where he's more comfortable, he hates hospitals, who doesn't....until any major changes we cant handle here, he's at home. But he has a great team started so lets see where this leads us, one day at a time.
Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone, I will keep up on posts. Nurse comes in Wednesday to figure out how his pain management regime is coming along. He's been on Morphine, Dilaudid, and Xanax twice a day, seems to work well. Zofran to keep his stomach calm with heartburn med. Still eliminating mucous/blood and some stool not much. His nutrition is made up of broth, some fruit, juices, water, occasional egg, soft foods if he can keep it down. Enjoys his new adjustable bed. Our dog of 5 1/2 yrs sometimes has this weird look like "whats going on". But he's very therapeutic! He does still get around, slow, but he does. The biggest challenge right now is lifting his legs up onto the bed. I do have a question? Is hospice suppose to be doing labs if they are managing his pain or no? They are starting him on a diuretic this week to help with swelling and ascites fluid buildup.
Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: My husbands PSA spiked to 157, spread to lymph nodes and spine, what am I to expect with treatments? I know the treatments can suppress but will it continue to spread if its in the lymphatic system?
Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: My husbands PSA spiked to 157, spread to lymph nodes and spine, what am I to expect with treatments? I know the treatments can suppress but will it continue to spread if its in the lymphatic system?
Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: My husband had hormone/injection therapy a year ago. They took a biopsy of the prostate and all came out 9s and 10s. Also metastasized to the seminal vesicles at the time. Radiation a year ago last August for 8 weeks, 5 days a week. PSA brought down to .04. Took Flomax and continue hormone treatment/injections to suppress. He ran out of prescription and thought he was done with treatment. Week ago last Sunday took him to the ER for abdominal pain, thought he was constipated, they took labs and found out his PSA was 157 again. So that changed everything. Cancer is still there but had spread to his lymph nodes and bones so basically its covered his whole pelvic area/abdomen and lumbar and thoracic, and of course now its in his blood stream. So Monday he starts his hormonal/injection treatments (Casodex/Firmagon) again and he cant stop now. Unfortunate lesson to learn that these treatments cant be stopped. Urologist said this is a rare very aggressive cancer and if the hormonal therapy does not work, chemo would be next but the prognosis is gloom at this point. Let me know if you guys concur with what they are telling me. I know the prognosis is different for everyone, but the more they say how aggressive this is the more I believe this will not be long I asked him what his Gleason/grade/score was he says "M" metastasis. What are the odds of this aggressive metastatic prostate cancer being from Chernobyl 20 years later?
Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: How strong is your Casodex George? How long did it take you to go from PSA 300+ down to the 6.78 in December?
Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: So what are the odds of the high PSA coming back after the combo hormone injection and chemo? What are the odds of PSA numbers increasing again after the chemo is done and only injections follow...for a stage 4....??
Posts.Title: High PSA coming back...

Posts.Content: Stage 4 existed for about a year or so before he added chemo in with his injections....so I guess you can say he didn't start the chemo early enough as well?
Posts.Title: High PSA coming back...

Posts.Content: I think this progressively came about over time but he was diagnosed in 2012 with an enlarged prostate and I believe there were symptoms before and just didn't realize what was going on until the prostate got large enough to cause problems, and then a year later cancer became very aggressive and promoted to metastasized prostate, i.e lymph nodes, bones, pelvic region....started out with hormone therapy injections for about 9 months then combined with chemo as of today, 4 out of 6 sessions so far. So its been three years since initial diagnosis.....we will see how long it will take with these injections before it decides it doesn't like it anymore. Chemo has been tough on him, but overall he's a trooper! It will be interesting to see what happens after the chemo stops and its back to just injections again. Last January his PSA was at around 175, and after we started the chemo with the injections, today its down to 3.19, and his blood work looks good.
Posts.Title: High PSA coming back...

Posts.Content: Stage 4 existed for about a year or so before he added chemo in with his injections....so I guess you can say he didn't start the chemo early enough as well?
Posts.Title: High PSA coming back...

Posts.Content: Hi guys how are you all doing. Its almost two months since my husband past.... still fighting the VA for benefits and his claim is still in appeals court.....Im sure it will take a life time more...but trying to be patient. Im doing ok, thought Id come on here and update everyone to let you know im ok, but struggling financially until they come up with something....if its ok I want to leave my link on here so if you all could help or share my link that would be outstanding. I hope everyone on here is doing ok and hanging in there. I know everyones situation is different and some very similar. Keep driving to get better, theres all kinds of research and trials out there. I hope you all find the right ones for you. Keep a smile on your face, we all get through it somehow.
Posts.Title: Husband died from cancer, Widow of Veteran in Need

Posts.Content: Thanks Lisa, yes I figured so...sorry.....yes its a grewling wait for benfits, it should be automatically for career families....system needs an overhaul for sure...

Posts.Content: rectal bleeding ok....but I looked and it was a big blob of blood clot in the toilet.....he just saw the dr, he has mild hydronephrosis in both kidneys and possibly a kidney stone they aren't sure yet until they study the images, he may need a ct scan to verify, but I guess it could also mean a blockage?
Posts.Title: blood clotty stools

Posts.Content: Anyone have their PSA numbers rise back up after chemo??
Posts.Title: PSA after chemo

Posts.Content: Anyone have any good experience with medicinal oils, not any specific ones, just any oils to help rid cancer or suppress it?
Posts.Title: Medicinal Oils

Posts.Content: I was thinking Provenge.......have to research Apalutamide....thanks Fairwind
Posts.Title: What's next?

Posts.Content: Well chemo is over, now its just HT again, switching to Lupron every 3 months.......its wait and see how it has mastered.....should we get bone scans etc again to see how well chemo/HT combo worked?
Posts.Title: Post Chemo

Posts.Content: So husband done with his series of Radium 223, new bone scan in 30 days, second month on Xtandi, seems to lower his PSA ok, not as drastic as other treatments but its keeping it down. After Xtandi, whats next? Not much out there.....any new trials out there anyone??
Posts.Title: What's next?

Posts.Content: I read about Provenge, he's too late in the stage to take it, he's already taking pain meds, and it said you cant use pain meds with this drug, its for earlier stages.....he cant use the other either.... so, Mr Oncologist, whats next? We will find out soon!
Posts.Title: What's next?

Posts.Content: So my husband has stomach problems.....every time he eats his stomach hurts and/or he is nauseous and starts sweating. Is this a normal reaction with this stage? And is it a warning sign when he starts losing weight and/or loses appetite? Any responses to this guys? Thanks!
Posts.Title: Stomach and eating problems with Metastatic Prostate Cancer Stage 4

Posts.Content: Well they say if the patient is losing weight its another sign of the disease progressing in the later days. Sometimes he loses his appetite, but its not too alarming yet. Im sure that all the drugs and radiation doesn't help much. But its hard to detect which way just yet....
Posts.Title: Stomach and eating problems with Metastatic Prostate Cancer Stage 4

Posts.Content: Yes my husband is wrapping up passing kidney stones also, so it does help. Ok. So he is continuing the Flomax. It helps!
Posts.Title: Flomax

Posts.Content: Anyone here has completed a hormone/chemo treatment, how are you doing today? Did it help? Anyone have bad side effects from chemo? Seems he's having bad intestinal response, always in the bathroom, bowels are loose, also associated with some pain as well. Any alarms with this one?
Posts.Title: Chemo/Hormone Combo

Posts.Content: Isn't Flomax only for when the prostate was enlarged, so you can pee? Why would you need it after the prostate has been radiated and shrunk? Or can it still become enlarged? hmmm
Posts.Title: Flomax

Posts.Content: Im not good at posting all the stats, its rather foreign. Id have to find the paperwork with all the scores on it and dates etc. and whatever history he's got, so ill work on that....when he's not on pain killers, he's got pelvic area pain. He's having depression and here and there. I guess only the patient knows. Dr says its very aggressive, and Im sure if he wasn't on any treatments at all it wouldn't take long to take over his body. Getting ready to have a pet/ct scan done, one that's more accurate to check on his bones. The conventional one was negative but Dr wants another because of his pain issue. A lot of them don't want to know "how long", it drives me crazy, I try to make him comfortable as much as possible and keep his spirits up but on the other hand Im one wanting to know dates about everything, so now I want to know what we're looking at, is that wrong to want to know, I would keep it to myself, he doesn t want to know anyway. I wonder if the Doc would tell me?

Posts.Content: Husbands platelets dropped to 32......blood counts messed up......Dr says likely cancer attached bones/bone marrow......got platelets and blood....get results on Tuesday....if they continue to drop, cant do any chemo, he's not in any shape to receive it. Cant do any trials either. What else can attack your blood like that? They took him off the steroids, he's on dilaudid, fentanyl for pain.

Posts.Content: Starting this chemo rather late, metastatic now for a year, how would it respond when he is just starting the chemo?
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: M1a and M1b means cancer spread to bones and lymph nodes, outside the primary site
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: Visit with Moffitt, time for chemo....aggressive cancer, aggressive treatments...chemo starts Friday for my husband. They are starting him on Docetaxel. This is all new for us, what to expect? Side effects, quality of life for the next 8 sessions? He's getting one hour, once every three weeks for about 8 sessions I believe. Anyone out there that took Docetaxel, how did it work for you? Im hangin in there. It gets tough when you find out there's more chemicals smothering his body, and hoping it works and there's some sort of remission...
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: M1a and M1b means cancer spread to bones and lymph nodes, outside the primary site
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: Starting this chemo rather late, metastatic now for a year, how would it respond when he is just starting the chemo?
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: I would think that depending on what stage you are at, will determine how you react to the chemo, I know everyone can be different. My husband is Stage IV, M1b, M1a, prostate cancer, so in my opinion, I would feel that he will not enjoy the side effects at this stage. Dr took him off the bicalutamide, wasn't helping and was causing too much dizziness. Im sure that will help. Never can be prepared enough for stuff like this, trusting in God and his guidance is a good way to go )
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: Casodex is failing, no longer working. Sooo, Dr is recommending taking a blood test, if accepted, to test for a mutation in his blood. This is for a new drug to fight down the cancer. Its a trial and his blood work is sent off to NC to be tested. Only 7 -8%, come out with a mutation in their blood, if he's clear then he can go ahead with the drug, if he's got this mutation, he will not be able to use the trial drug. Any thoughts on this? I have to go look at this paperwork to get you the name of the drug they want to use. But anyone doing this already? Or any other thoughts on this?
Posts.Title: Anyone here trying a clinical trial involving a blood test?

Posts.Content: I would think that depending on what stage you are at, will determine how you react to the chemo, I know everyone can be different. My husband is Stage IV, M1b, M1a, prostate cancer, so in my opinion, I would feel that he will not enjoy the side effects at this stage. Dr took him off the bicalutamide, wasn't helping and was causing too much dizziness. Im sure that will help. Never can be prepared enough for stuff like this, trusting in God and his guidance is a good way to go )
